title: Additive energies of subsets of discrete cubes
abstract:
For a positive integer $n \geq 2$, define $t_n$ to be the smallest number
such that the additive energy $E(A)$ of any subset $A \subset
\{0,1,\cdots,n-1\}^d$ and any $d$ is at most $|A|^{t_n}$. Trivially we have
$t_n \leq 3$ and $$ t_n \geq 3 - \log_n\frac{3n^3}{2n^3+n} $$ by considering $A
= \{0,1,\cdots,n-1\}^d$. In this note, we investigate the behavior of $t_n$ for
large $n$ and obtain the following non-trivial bounds: $$ 3 -
(1+o_{n\rightarrow\infty}(1)) \log_n \frac{3\sqrt{3}}{4} \leq t_n \leq 3 -
\log_n(1+c), $$ where $c>0$ is an absolute constant.
